Write a summary of the following passage :

Sheikh Kamal knew that there is no shortcut to success. He groomed himself up as a young man who earned success by dint of perseverance and commitment. When the Pakistan military began its genocide in Bangladesh, he joined the Liberation War and received military training at Camp Murtee located at the Himalayan foothills in India. The tall young man who carried himself with dignity and possessed remarkable traits of leadership became the ADC of General Ataul Goni, Osmani, the Commander in Chief of Bangladesh Armed Forces during the Liberation War. After Independence, Sheikh Kamal could, easily remain in Bangladesh Army and pass a secure life but he preferred to engage himself in country building and organizing the young forces to that end, Journalist Syed Ishtiaq Rezi in one of his columns 'Ekjon Sheikh Kamal' in Bangla Tribune rightly says that the unique qualities of Sheikh Kamal's character, especially his wholehearted involvement in sports and culture are never seen in any son or daughter of any President, Prime Minister or High Officials in Bangladesh.

sub_questions.explanation: Sheikh Kamal exemplified perseverance and commitment, earning success through hard work. He joined the Liberation War during the Pakistan military's genocide in Bangladesh, receiving military training in India and serving as ADC to General Osmani. After independence, instead of pursuing a secure military career, he focused on nation-building and youth organization. Renowned for his involvement in sports and culture, his unique qualities distinguished him from other political figures' offspring in Bangladesh, as noted by journalist Syed Ishtiaq Rezi

questions.uddipok:
Read the following beginning of a story and develop it into a complete story. Give a suitable title to your story (in around 200 words).
Once upon a time, there was a pond full of frogs. As it was during the rainy season, it was filled to brim with water. Many frogs took their shelter in the pond......

sub_questions.explanation:
The Proud Frog and the Pond
Once upon a time, there was a pond full of frogs. As it was during the rainy season, it was filled to the brim with water. Many frogs took shelter in the pond, jumping, playing, and croaking all day long. The pond was lively and cheerful.
Among them was a proud frog who believed he was the biggest and strongest of all. He would often boast about his strength and size to the other frogs, claiming that he could defeat any creature that came near the pond.
One day, a group of travelers passed by the pond with a large ox. The frogs curiously peeked from the water to see the huge animal. The proud frog, seeing the ox, felt his pride hurt. “That creature may be big,” he said loudly, “but I can be just as big if I want to!”
He began puffing himself up. “Look! Am I as big as that ox now?” he asked the other frogs.
“No, not yet,” replied the frogs.
The proud frog puffed himself up even more. “Now?”
“Still not as big,” they said.
Angry and determined, the proud frog puffed and puffed, trying to become as large as the ox. But in his foolish attempt, he puffed so much that his body couldn’t handle it. With a loud pop! , he burst and died on the spot.
All the other frogs were shocked and saddened. They had tried to warn him, but his pride had made him blind to reason.
Moral: Pride and envy can lead to one's downfall. Be content with who you are and never try to be someone you're not.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Rafa. Write an e-mail to your foreign friend narrating the scenic beauty of Bangladesh.

sub_questions.explanation:
Subject: Exploring the Enchanting Landscapes of Bangladesh
Hey [Friend's Name],
I hope this email finds you in good spirits! I've been meaning to share some of the incredible experiences I've had recently, particularly exploring the breathtaking beauty of Bangladesh. Trust me, it's been nothing short of mesmerizing!
Let me paint you a picture of the landscapes that have left me in awe. Picture lush green fields stretching as far as the eye can see, with vibrant hues of paddy swaying gently in the breeze. The countryside here is like something out of a postcard, with quaint villages nestled amidst rolling hills and meandering rivers.
Speaking of rivers, you wouldn't believe the majesty of the mighty Padma, Meghna, and Jamuna rivers that crisscross the land. These waterways are not just lifelines for transportation and trade but also sources of timeless beauty. At sunset, the skies are set ablaze with hues of orange and pink, casting a magical glow over the tranquil waters below.
But it's not just the rural landscapes that steal the show; Bangladesh's coastal regions are a sight to behold as well. Miles of pristine sandy beaches stretch along the coastline, fringed by swaying palms and dotted with colorful fishing boats. And let me tell you about the Sundarbans, the world's largest mangrove forest. Navigating through its intricate network of waterways, surrounded by dense foliage and exotic wildlife, feels like stepping into a world untouched by time.
Of course, no discussion of Bangladesh's beauty would be complete without mentioning its vibrant cities. Dhaka, the bustling capital, is a whirlwind of sights and sounds, where ancient mosques and modern skyscrapers coexist harmoniously. The streets are alive with the hustle and bustle of daily life, and the air is infused with the aroma of delicious street food.
I could go on and on about the wonders of Bangladesh, but I'll leave it at that for now. Suffice it to say, this country has stolen a piece of my heart with its unparalleled beauty and warm hospitality. I can't wait for you to experience it for yourself someday.
Until then, take care, and keep dreaming of distant shores!
Warm regards,
Rafa
